TITLE I--MOTOR VEHICLE SAFETY

SEC. 101. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Section 30104 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to authorize $125,221,000 for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for fiscal year 2005, with additional funding for fiscal years 2006 and 2007.

SEC. 102. INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION. SEC. 102. INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION. The Secretary of Transportation may participate in international activities to enhance motor vehicle and traffic safety through exchanging information, conducting safety research, and implementing existing international agreements. SEC. 103. Certification labels require tests or documentation for compliance with safety standards. Manufacturers can rely on compliance documentation from earlier stages. SEC. 104. Notification of noncompliance. SEC. 104. NOTIFICATION OF NONCOMPLIANCE. Amends Section 30118 of title 49, United States Code to include original equipment in notification of noncompliance. SEC. 105. NOTIFICATION OF AND REMEDIES FOR NONCOMPLIANCE. Section 30120 of title 49, United States Code, now includes a limitation on the sale or lease of used motor vehicles. Dealers must inform purchasers or lessees of any defects or noncompliance issues, offer to remedy them, or provide a written description of the issues along with relevant information from notifications. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for dealers selling used motor vehicles, defining a dealer as someone who sold at least 10 vehicles in the past 12 months to non-resale purchasers. It also defines a used motor vehicle as one previously purchased for non-resale purposes. The Secretary may specify a time period for compliance with these requirements. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for manufacturers to establish an Internet-accessible record system for dealers and the public to check for vehicle defects. Manufacturers may be exempted if deemed impracticable. Additionally, there are limitations on the operation of school buses and vehicles used for passenger transportation. The curr_chunk states that a person who owns or leases a school bus or a vehicle used for passenger transportation must not operate the vehicle if a defect or noncompliance notice has been received until the issue is resolved. This rule does not apply to taxicabs or vehicles owned by State or local governments. SEC. 106 prohibits the use of safety belt interlocks in motor vehicles as a compliance measure with safety standards. SEC. 107 focuses on research, testing, development, and training in the transportation industry. Section 30168 of title 49, United States Code, authorizes $5,000,000 per year for a safety research initiative for alternate fuel vehicles. This includes risk assessment studies, development of test procedures, and investigation of power train and fuel system safety. The Secretary is authorized to expend $10,000,000 per year for research on driver assistance technologies to ensure safety benefits are derived from these advancements, including crash avoidance technologies like electronic stability control and radar braking. TITLE II--MOTOR VEHICLE INFORMATION AND COST SAVINGS

SEC. 201. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

    Section 32102 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to authorize $14,080,000 for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in fiscal year 2005, with additional funding for fiscal years 2006 and 2007.

SEC. 202. PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT.

    Penalties under Section 32709(a)(1) of title 49, United States Code, are increased to $5,000 and $1,000,000.

SEC. 203. CIVIL ACTIONS BY PRIVATE PERSON.

    The amount for civil actions under Section 32710(a) of title 49, United States Code, is raised to $10,000.

SEC. 204. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 204. DEFINITIONS.

    Crash avoidance is defined as preventing a motor vehicle accident.

SEC. 205. REPEALS. SEC. 205. REPEALS. Sections 32303 and 33112 of title 49, United States Code, are repealed. Amendments are made to the table of sections for chapters 323 and 331 by striking the items related to these sections.
